name: Ghent
fun_fact: Fun fact: Ghent's Tierenteyn mustard shop has been selling only ONE type of mustard since 1867 - a fiery blend of 27 different mustard seeds that's hot without being eye-watering. The mustard is pumped from the cellar into a wooden barrel, then hand-scooped into stone pots. No other products, no variations, just pure mustardy perfection for over 150 years.

hero_dishes.name: Gentse Waterzooi
hero_dishes.description: Creamy fish or chicken stew/soup made with vegetables and herbs in a rich broth, dating back to the Middle Ages
hero_dishes.origin_story: Originally made with fresh fish from the Lys and Scheldt rivers in medieval times. Modern versions often use chicken. The name roughly translates to 'watery mess' but it's a beloved comfort food holding a special place in Ghent residents' hearts.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Du Progres (three generations of family-run brasserie, 'een vaste waarde' - trusty go-to, reservations essential), Raadkamer (best authentic fish version), 't Klokhuys (Patershol district, charming brasserie with exposed beams), Restaurant Neptune (Sint-Veerleplein 10, near the castle)

hero_dishes.name: Stoverij (Stoofvlees - Flemish Beef Stew)
hero_dishes.description: Beef or pork stew slow-cooked in dark Trappist beer, creating rich, deep flavors. Pork cheek version with Westmalle beer and Tierenteyn mustard is particularly notable
hero_dishes.origin_story: The real Belgian stoofvlees is always prepared in beer - preferably dark beer, with Trappist being the ultimate. This slow-braised dish represents the heart of Belgian comfort food.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Du Progres (traditional preparation for three generations), Restaurant Neptune (beef in beer stew is a specialty)

hero_dishes.name: Paling in 't Groen (Eel in Green Sauce)
hero_dishes.description: Eels cooked in a vibrant green herb sauce, a veritable icon of Belgian gastronomy
hero_dishes.origin_story: Traditional Belgian specialty showcasing the country's unique culinary heritage. The green sauce is made with fresh herbs creating a distinctive flavor.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Brasserie Savarin (located at Vrijdagmarkt, serves several eel dishes including this specialty)

hero_dishes.name: Belgian Shrimp Specialties
hero_dishes.description: Shrimp croquettes and shrimp-stuffed tomatoes made with Belgian gray shrimp, very unique to Belgian gastronomy
hero_dishes.origin_story: Belgian gray shrimp from the North Sea give these dishes their distinctive flavor. The croquettes are crispy outside, creamy inside.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional brasseries throughout Ghent, food markets

signature_drinks.name: Gentse Gruut Beer
signature_drinks.description: Beer brewed with a blend of herbs (gruut) instead of hops, following pre-hop medieval brewing traditions
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Visit the Gentse Gruut brewery for tours showcasing this historical brewing method. The brewery offers a range of herb-flavored beers demonstrating how beer was made before hops became standard.

signature_drinks.name: Gentse Strop
signature_drinks.description: Blond beer (6% alcohol) undeniably connected with Ghent, brewed by Roman brewery in Oudenaarde, launched May 2011
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: The name relates to a historical event when Emperor Charles V marched Ghent's notables barefoot with nooses (strop) around their necks to beg mercy. To be a 'Stroppendrager' (noose bearer) is now a badge of honor for Ghentians. Served throughout the city as a symbol of local pride.

food_culture_notes: Du Progres is known among Ghent residents as 'een vaste waarde' (trusty go-to) - reservations are a must
The Great Butchers' Hall (Groot Vleeshuis) dates to the 15th century, now showcases East Flanders regional specialties
Specialty foods include Gentse Ganda ham (10+ months to dry), artisanal cheeses, and fine meats
Cuberdons ('neuzekes' - little purple noses) are sold by two competing vendors at Lange Munt by Himschoot bakery
Real cuberdons are purple with violet or raspberry syrup under harder exterior
Gentse Mokken are aniseed biscuits sold at Confiserie Temmerman on Kraanlei 79
Temmerman is Ghent's famous candy shop for local sweets
Food markets at Vrijdagmarkt and Sint-Michielsplein offer local and international foods
Frietjes (Belgian fries) are usually served with mayonnaise, not ketchup

unique_modern: Competing cuberdon vendors creating local rivalry
Historic butchers' hall converted to gourmet food showcase
